headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Public Storage First Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] .It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to Ryan Burke, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ryan,
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the Public Storage First Quarter 2019 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] .
It is now my pleasure to turn the floor over to Ryan Burke, Vice President of Investor Relations. Ryan, you may begin.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Lori. Good day, everyone. Thank you for joining us for the first quarter 2019 earnings call. I'm here with Joe Russell and Tom Boyle. Before we begin, we want to remind you that all statements, other than statements of historical fact include
componenttext:
Thank you, Lori. Good day, everyone. Thank you for joining us for the first quarter 2019 earnings call. I'm here with Joe Russell and Tom Boyle. 
Before we begin, we want to remind you that all statements, other than statements of historical fact included on this call, are forward-looking statements that are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties that could cause actual results to differ materially from those projected by those statements. These risks and other factors could adversely affect our business and future results that are described in yesterday's earnings release and in our reports filed with the SEC. All forward-looking statements speak only as of today, May 2, 2019, and we assume no obligation to update or revise any forward-looking statements, whether as a result of new information, future events or otherwise. 
A reconciliation to GAAP of the non-GAAP financial measures we provide on this call is included in our earnings release. You can find our earnings release, SEC reports and an audio webcast replay of this conference call on our website at publicstorage.com. 
With that, I'll turn the call over to Joe.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Ryan, and thank you all for joining us. We had a good quarter, and I'd like to open the call for questions.
componenttext: Great. Thanks, Ryan, and thank you all for joining us. We had a good quarter, and I'd like to open the call for questions.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Shirley Wu of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your first question comes from the line of Shirley Wu of Bank of America Merrill Lynch.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: So my first question is in regards to revenue growth. Over the last few quarters, you've ranged in between 1.2% to 1.5% for revenue growth. And your period on data would suggest that revenue would stay in that range for 2Q. So it seems like things have be
componenttext: So my first question is in regards to revenue growth. Over the last few quarters, you've ranged in between 1.2% to 1.5% for revenue growth. And your period on data would suggest that revenue would stay in that range for 2Q. So it seems like things have been fairly steady and have missed all this new supply. Given the resilience of demand, how do you feel revenue growth to come play out in '19 and any thoughts on when revenues to drop?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Great. Thanks, Shirley. I can comment on that. I think, you gave a pretty good summary of what our historical revenue growth has been over the previous quarters. And you do point to the period end occupancy and contract rent growth, which do suggest we en
componenttext:
Great. Thanks, Shirley. I can comment on that. I think, you gave a pretty good summary of what our historical revenue growth has been over the previous quarters. And you do point to the period end occupancy and contract rent growth, which do suggest we ended the quarter in a place where contract rents would be growing at the start of April at a similar level. So I think, we've been encouraged by customer trends like we spoke about on our last call, really a combination of a tougher move-in environment, balanced really by continued good performance by existing tenant base and our existing tenants. We see move outs down and length of stay moderately increasing and they're all being supported by a strong labor market out there in the broader macro economy. 
So we've seen good operating trends consistent with what we discussed on our last call, reasonably steady contract rent growth and occupancy through the quarter. In terms of where we go from here, we're obviously at the end of the first quarter, we're about to enter into our seasonally busy move-in time as we get into May and June that'll be a big determinant of overall 2019 revenue trend and we'll certainly update you on those trends on our next quarterly call.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Surely, I'll just add the other thing that we've been seeing and we're pleased to see is we're maneuvering through and navigating through what continues to be commanding arena of new supply in certain markets. Some of that's been shifting out of markets m
componenttext: Surely, I'll just add the other thing that we've been seeing and we're pleased to see is we're maneuvering through and navigating through what continues to be commanding arena of new supply in certain markets. Some of that's been shifting out of markets more heavily say over the last 2 to 3 years, we still got other markets ahead of us that are likely to see somewhat similar impact going into '19 and 2020. But, again, to Tom's point, we're feeling better and we like what we're seeing relative to the traction and capabilities of that we're putting into many parts of the business to maneuver through this environment.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. So moving to street rates. How has 1Q trended? And even if 2Q, and also, your move-in rates as well?
componenttext: Okay. So moving to street rates. How has 1Q trended? And even if 2Q, and also, your move-in rates as well?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Great. So, as you know, we've spoken on the previous calls, we don't tend to watch street rates too closely. Street rates were actually up a little over 1% in the quarter, but we focused on move-in rates as they are actually the rates that customers will
componenttext: Great. So, as you know, we've spoken on the previous calls, we don't tend to watch street rates too closely. Street rates were actually up a little over 1% in the quarter, but we focused on move-in rates as they are actually the rates that customers will be paying us. Move-in rates as we disclosed in our 10-Q last night were down for the quarter, down 1%, that's the best move-in rate performance we've seen in some time. And we did see move-in volume down modestly in the quarter, but again, offset by move-out volumes being down as well. In terms of rent rolldown, this is a seasonally one of the bigger rent rolldown quarters, given the slower move-in season and the fact that folks have moved in at higher rates through the summer. And so we did continue to see it rent rolldown of the quarter, which deteriorated modestly. But again, one of the better performances in rent rolldown deceleration.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got it. So would you say move-in rates are time persisted, negative 1% since April as well?
componenttext: Got it. So would you say move-in rates are time persisted, negative 1% since April as well?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. We're seeing consistent trends in April. And that's really a balance of all of the markets in which we have operations. So you look at certain markets like an L.A. on West Coast or some of our stronger East Coast markets, which have good positive mov
componenttext: Yes. We're seeing consistent trends in April. And that's really a balance of all of the markets in which we have operations. So you look at certain markets like an L.A. on West Coast or some of our stronger East Coast markets, which have good positive move-in rent performance. And then as Joe highlighted, the markets were being impacted by new supply. We do see a negative move-in rates continuing into 2019. So markets like Houston, which were lapping hurricane benefit in prior year, I would lump into that group as well.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz of BMO.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz of BMO.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Joe, you touched on navigating supply just a minute ago, but can you just give a broader view on supply as we look into 2019? And any early read on 2020? And whether those views have changed or how they changed at all as we moved a little further into the
componenttext: Joe, you touched on navigating supply just a minute ago, but can you just give a broader view on supply as we look into 2019? And any early read on 2020? And whether those views have changed or how they changed at all as we moved a little further into the year?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Sure, Jeremy. I would say there's really no change on what, again, our outlook is from even 60 days ago, from our last call. So everything we're tracking points to 2019 to be again get another pretty commanding year of deliveries plus or minus in tha
componenttext:
Yes. Sure, Jeremy. I would say there's really no change on what, again, our outlook is from even 60 days ago, from our last call. So everything we're tracking points to 2019 to be again get another pretty commanding year of deliveries plus or minus in that $5 billion range, say 400 to 500 properties plus or minus 30 million square feet. So the one thing as I noted a few minutes ago, it is shifting somewhat. So if it's encouraging that all, which we like to see, fewer deliveries are taking place in Denver, Charlotte, Houston, often in Tampa, for instance. So there's been a pull back there. That's good news. But some developers are starting to get more active in Portland, Boston, Seattle, Miami and New York. 
So we're keeping a close eye on any residual impact that the supply is likely to have this year and going into next year. The same drivers out there that has fueled this level of supply over the last 2 to 3 years, in particular,, which is a lot of new entrants are still coming into the sector. You've got developers that like the potential yields are likely to derive from the new development, and fundings out there. So we're keeping a close eye on it. We're looking at 2020 as potentially a year that things could start shifting down, but again, we've got to track it and see what's at hand. I'll tell you and maybe even to shift a little bit into how that's affecting the acquisition environment. There are a number of conversations that are becoming more pronounced, which are laced around the theme of I want out. Now again, not out because it's a stressful situation or it's one that necessarily is commanding that decision at a level that I've got to get out, but it's a realization that maybe returns not going to be met. They may have some lender pressure, maybe expectations from a revenue or performance standpoint aren't there. 
So that is a residual effect and potentially a good thing that we're going to continue to see. So if you even look at as you saw through the first quarter and what we reported relative to what we have under contract, we've now even through the earlier part of this year exceeded the acquisition volume we did in all 2018. And there are some interesting things as a part of that collection of acquisitions. One, for instance, is for the first time in several years, we have a property that we're acquiring out of bankruptcy. So I've talked about that a little bit over the last few quarters, meaning that we think some of that kind of acquisition opportunity can surface and we've got one, again, under contract. 
We bought a portfolio in the first quarter, 9 properties, great assets, long-term ownership and the deal came to us on an off market basis, but again, the owners decided it was for them the right time to exit the sector entirely. And it was a good negotiation, meaning, it was a deal that was fair priced. It wasn't one that they looked at was one that had to meet or get a top level of evaluation, but it was a deal they wanted to do on a very efficient and clean basis and we were an ideal candidate to do that. So there's more of that in the mix as we speak and we're encouraged by that. And we'll see how the rest of the year plays out.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: And is some of that driving just maybe the price per pound here we're seeing just in terms of some of the pipeline and just looking at the market mix those are high-cost markets like say in New York, but [indiscernible] that equates around $60 or $70 a fo
componenttext: And is some of that driving just maybe the price per pound here we're seeing just in terms of some of the pipeline and just looking at the market mix those are high-cost markets like say in New York, but [indiscernible] that equates around $60 or $70 a foot, and I know replacement cost is core to your buying for so does any of that factoring into that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, a little bit of them mix on average is driving that a little higher than maybe what you've seen us do in a few prior quarters as some of our acquisitions on the pipeline right now are in more urban markets and higher finished assets, newer assets th
componenttext: Well, a little bit of them mix on average is driving that a little higher than maybe what you've seen us do in a few prior quarters as some of our acquisitions on the pipeline right now are in more urban markets and higher finished assets, newer assets that we think not only are very well located, but very hard to duplicate. Again, with the same theme that owners are coming to us and saying, okay, we may not need or exceed the type of returns we expected 2 or 3 years ago when we put these properties into development. They're not, by any means, failed assets, but again, actual expectations are not being met. So we've got to peel those in our pipeline right now under contracted are extremely well located, great assets, handful of them might be a little bit higher on average than you've seen us do in some of the other markets that we bought assets in, but we still feel great replacement cost, deals, we're going to get very good returns. And again, we hope to see more of that kind of activity throughout this year.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Definitely appreciate that. Last one from me. I just wondered if you could give a quick update on third-party management initiative? And on that front, are you actually seeing anyone out there jumping platforms between the bigger operators you do third-pa
componenttext: Definitely appreciate that. Last one from me. I just wondered if you could give a quick update on third-party management initiative? And on that front, are you actually seeing anyone out there jumping platforms between the bigger operators you do third-party? I know, historically, that really haven't had much of the happening, but are you seeing any of that at least on the margin?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: So on the quarter we signed 11 properties into the platform. Our backlog continues to grow. It's heavily weighted by development deals that will take a number of quarters to actually come to completion and be pulled directly into the program itself. We're
componenttext: So on the quarter we signed 11 properties into the platform. Our backlog continues to grow. It's heavily weighted by development deals that will take a number of quarters to actually come to completion and be pulled directly into the program itself. We're seeing and learning a lot of interesting things through the platform. And yes, I would tell you some of that includes, which I don't think at the end of the day is may be new to the business but there are certain owners that do change flags. So whether they're coming to us through either private or another public third-party platform, we're seeing some of that, but I wouldn't tell you that's the dominant part of the activity in our backlog. It's still highly correlated to deals that are in various forms of development. But we like what we would see relative to the type of assets that are coming to us. We've actually, at the end of the day, passed as many properties as we've decided to pull in to the platforms for a number of reasons. So I think, we've got the ability to continue to be particularly cautious about what markets that some of these assets come to us and whether or not we choose to go into those or other factors, but again, we feel like overtime, we'll be able to grow the scale of business and keep good momentum around it itself. So that's where we stand as we speak.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of Citi.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of Citi.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: I just, I wanted to ask you a little bit about marketing expenses in the quarter, second quarter pretty big increases year-over-year. Do you expect that pace to kind of continue through the balance of the year? And I guess, along with that, it sounds like
componenttext: I just, I wanted to ask you a little bit about marketing expenses in the quarter, second quarter pretty big increases year-over-year. Do you expect that pace to kind of continue through the balance of the year? And I guess, along with that, it sounds like you are seeing some stabilization throughout your system a little bit and I mean do you attribute it to maybe changes in the way that you're marketing on the Internet versus other ways or can you just give some color around that?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. So let me take that in some different components. So the marketing spend that we saw in the quarter was pretty consistent rate of increase from the fourth quarter. And as we discussed last time, we did that in the fourth quarter really throughout 20
componenttext:
Sure. So let me take that in some different components. So the marketing spend that we saw in the quarter was pretty consistent rate of increase from the fourth quarter. And as we discussed last time, we did that in the fourth quarter really throughout 2018 and increased our spend as we saw good demand response online and great reaction to our brand in online paid search. That's combined with more competitive environment on paid search, as you'd expect in any markets impacted by new supply, the cost of acquiring customers is increasing as that supply is getting absorbed. And so there is some market costs-per-click increases in there as well. Ultimately, our decision-making around that is very dynamic, based on key words and local market dynamics and traffic. So I'm not going to call a rate of increase for the rest of the year, but it's a tool that we're seeing good returns on today and we're continuing as we get in through the second quarter to use that tool. 
That -- the second part of the question was, is that benefiting the overall level of movement activity. And certainly, the answer to that is yes. We do like the demand response we're seeing from that channel, but we're using a combination of advertising rates, which, again, the rates were down about 1% for move-in for the quarter and promotions to drive traffic to our stores. In terms of the third component of your question, which is around, is it contributing to stabilization of the portfolio in aggregate. I guess, I would say, we're seeing good trends in advertising, helping move ins, but move ins remain challenging in many markets, and so that's where our increased spend is concentrated and in other markets where move-in trends are quite good and healthy. In terms of the stabilization point, we have seen some good trends in some of the early markets that were hit by new supply. So we you'll see markets like Washington, D.C. or Chicago improving. D.C. is up 180 basis points in occupancy for us year-over-year. Chicago is up 160 basis points. So we are seeing some improved trends there.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to circle back to development. It looks, your development and expense pipeline decreased specifically and I know you delivered a few stores in the quarter but how is activity looking to back fill the pipeline? Is public pipeline selling down
componenttext: I just wanted to circle back to development. It looks, your development and expense pipeline decreased specifically and I know you delivered a few stores in the quarter but how is activity looking to back fill the pipeline? Is public pipeline selling down here or is it just timing related?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, Todd, first of all, we had an active Q1. So a lot of the pipeline delivered in the quarter, we have about [ 137 million ] of deliveries for new builds, but really drove the volume was a number of redevelopments heavily tied to the remaining scrape an
componenttext:
Yes, Todd, first of all, we had an active Q1. So a lot of the pipeline delivered in the quarter, we have about [ 137 million ] of deliveries for new builds, but really drove the volume was a number of redevelopments heavily tied to the remaining scrape and rebuilds in Houston specifically. So we hadn't elevated the level of first quarter volume. So to a degree, some of that impacted the pipeline. The pipeline did shift down close to $100 million or so, but that can ebb and flow. I wouldn't take that as indication that overall we've intentionally tapered that down on just 1 or 2 quarter basis. We're seeing a lot of good continued potential activity out there. It has shifted intentionally more than our redevelopment activity where we're taking existing properties and putting a lot of the attributes from what we call our Gen 5 new product into properties that are extremely well located, where we can expand and increase, not only performance but scale in certain markets where otherwise you'd never be able to get to those freight land sites. 
So we see continued very active activity on that front today about 60-plus percent of our development pipelines tied to that. And the teams are out looking for land sites in a variety of different markets. In some markets, lands becoming more expensive, so we're keeping a close eye on the impact to that. The other thing that is happening is the time to entitle, it seems to be certainly a number of markets getting more commanding. Now the reverse of that, which kind of ties to some of the impact with either developers or entrance that have come into the markets over the last 2 or 3 years. We are getting reverse increase more than we've seen recently for close to our fully entitled land sites. So again, we've got a healthy collection of different opportunities there. And the teams every bit as focused on how driving that kind of opportunity and we continue to see very good returns from our investments into the developed pipeline.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, and Tom, you mentioned the cost to acquire customer continues to rise. Can you share with us what that cost is today? And maybe discuss how that's trended?
componenttext: Okay. And then, and Tom, you mentioned the cost to acquire customer continues to rise. Can you share with us what that cost is today? And maybe discuss how that's trended?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. The cost has modestly increased and certainly the advertising spend is a component of it -- another component you can track in our disclosures and 10-Q is the promotional discounts that really comes in the form of the $1 for the first month rent for
componenttext: Sure. The cost has modestly increased and certainly the advertising spend is a component of it -- another component you can track in our disclosures and 10-Q is the promotional discounts that really comes in the form of the $1 for the first month rent for Public Storage, which is a great way to drive traffic to our stores. Those are the 2 large components of customer acquisition costs. So you can take a look at those in our filings.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's fine. And then, just lastly, can you just talk about your plans to run, I think, previously was the Memorial Day sale this month in May, whether you're planning to and how discounting and promotions are sort of shaping up for the busy season
componenttext: Okay. That's fine. And then, just lastly, can you just talk about your plans to run, I think, previously was the Memorial Day sale this month in May, whether you're planning to and how discounting and promotions are sort of shaping up for the busy season in general?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we typically do run some sales as we go through the summer months and we're seeing good returns on that in the past. It's something that we'll dynamically assess as we go through the quarter and we'll update you as to where we go. In terms of pro
componenttext: Sure. So we typically do run some sales as we go through the summer months and we're seeing good returns on that in the past. It's something that we'll dynamically assess as we go through the quarter and we'll update you as to where we go. In terms of promotional trends, you could see promotional dollars were down in the quarter that's really driven by volume and rate decreases, not a strategy change there. So we continue to use that dollars special to drive traffic into our stores. I would expect consistent strategies this year as last year, but obviously if anything changes, we'll let  you know.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019

componenttext: If I could go back to the marketing spend, just curious obviously, it's pretty local but is there any kind of high-level discernible themes in terms of where these dollars are going? So to set another way, is it more West Coast markets versus East Coast, maybe more supply challenge or is sort of the increase spend all across the board and hard to pick up?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. In terms of where it's located geographically, the increase our spend is across the board. I think there are certain markets as I highlighted that spend is more -- increased more than others, and that's really driven by the competitive dynamic as cu
componenttext: Sure. In terms of where it's located geographically, the increase our spend is across the board. I think there are certain markets as I highlighted that spend is more -- increased more than others, and that's really driven by the competitive dynamic as customers are competed for on Google and other online platforms. So the overall spend costs are higher across the board, but it is concentrated in markets where the competitive dynamics are more intense.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019

componenttext: Great. Other question was, which I think, I believe, there was a website Refresh for the company such this quarter. I think the idea was hopefully it would kind of tie into your ability to market online. May be can you give us an update on that? And how that's receiving what you're seeing there?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure, Ron, I'll start and Tom can add on this too. So, yes, we delivered, I would label our generation or fifth-generation website in the first quarter. So it's a project that gone through a variety of different testing, et cetera, as we roll it out throu
componenttext: Sure, Ron, I'll start and Tom can add on this too. So, yes, we delivered, I would label our generation or fifth-generation website in the first quarter. So it's a project that gone through a variety of different testing, et cetera, as we roll it out through the entire platform. So we're pleased thus far by what we're seeing. Is going to give us additional capabilities that we've been able to add, not from a need standpoint, but from an opportunity standpoint. All indications are the tools that's going to provide us are going to be quite commanding in a number of ways. So we're anxious to continue to roll those out as we go through the rest of this year. And Tom, you can give some additional color on it.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. And I think we covered it well Joe. I think, it's built to be mobile centric as customers continue to move to transact with us on their phones as we continue to see that trend play out and really something that has played out over the last decade. An
componenttext: Yes. And I think we covered it well Joe. I think, it's built to be mobile centric as customers continue to move to transact with us on their phones as we continue to see that trend play out and really something that has played out over the last decade. And so you'll see that as you pull out the new publicstorage.com, but we're pleased with it and team worked hard on it and we're happy to have it delivered in the first quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. My last question, I think you made some interesting comments about sort of the environment and opportunities out there. Just curious on just thinking about lease up and lease up times. Obviously, you're in the market looking at properties and you've
componenttext: Yes. My last question, I think you made some interesting comments about sort of the environment and opportunities out there. Just curious on just thinking about lease up and lease up times. Obviously, you're in the market looking at properties and you've got to see that's delivered. How does that -- how are you guys thinking about or how does that trended over the last year or so when you're running the pro forma, are you assuming longer lease up times and just can you quantify that for us?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. I wouldn't say there's been a shift at all. I mean, again, you go back to the fundamental way that a lease up can typically happen on a property. And frankly, it can range from anywhere from 2 to 3 years on an average basis. So not really seeing any
componenttext:
Yes. I wouldn't say there's been a shift at all. I mean, again, you go back to the fundamental way that a lease up can typically happen on a property. And frankly, it can range from anywhere from 2 to 3 years on an average basis. So not really seeing any different time frames tied to that. In certain markets, where supply may be more pronounced, you may have elongated lease up or some impact from that then alternatively. Some markets that do have fair amount of suppliers still doing quite well because there's an inherent need and the market itself may be underserved and that frankly, is the reason why we chose to develop those specific asset that are in the first place. 
And then, another part of the the mix that we have out there is that we've got other assets that are clearly well ahead of our expectations. And we're seeing very good traction in a number of properties that are, again, ahead from that standpoint as well. The thing that is a natural part of our business as a whole is it not only is it is a factor of lease up, but it's a majority of the lease property property itself. And what do I mean that the inventory leases are hand take a fair amount of time to mature and stabilize because you're going to see good growth and you're going to see good factors tied to that but that time needs to mature so that, again, you've got a highly stabilize asset and you're able to evaluate it to ultimate success.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: This is Tom. You can see that in our 2013 to 2015 development vintages that as Joe highlighted, they leased up well and they continue to stabilize. And so you could see the growth in the quarter of 10%, 11% for that group as it continues to season. And we
componenttext: This is Tom. You can see that in our 2013 to 2015 development vintages that as Joe highlighted, they leased up well and they continue to stabilize. And so you could see the growth in the quarter of 10%, 11% for that group as it continues to season. And we certainly provide that disclosure so you can evaluate the performance of those stores as well as the other development and expansion vintages that we've been active in delivering.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019

componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa of Evercore ISI.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: I guess, a number of my operating questions have been asked but I just want to touch on the balance sheet quickly, Tom. I mean, obviously you guys recently did a longer term bond issuance and historically you've used preferred to kind of fund the company
componenttext: I guess, a number of my operating questions have been asked but I just want to touch on the balance sheet quickly, Tom. I mean, obviously you guys recently did a longer term bond issuance and historically you've used preferred to kind of fund the company again. Just trying to get a update on sort of your thought process there. You do have a couple of preferred issuances that are callable later this year. And I'm just kind of wondering what your thought processes longer-term about using more debt?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Steve. So we have issued both preferred and bonds throughout the year. We continue to remain committed to both markets as good financing tools. We've talked about in the past, the preferred market is a great long-term permanent source of cap
componenttext:
Sure. Thanks, Steve. So we have issued both preferred and bonds throughout the year. We continue to remain committed to both markets as good financing tools. We've talked about in the past, the preferred market is a great long-term permanent source of capital with lots of great features, including the call feature and the permanent life. With our balance sheet, we also have the ability to add incremental long-term debt to finance our external growth pipelines, both the acquisition activity as well as the development pipeline. 
So we'll look to use both sources of capital going forward. You highlighted that we do have some callable preferreds outstanding. We also have some new callable preferreds later in the year that will evaluate. In the month of March, we did execute a deferred financing as well as a redemption that lowered our aggregate to have preferred cost of 5.3%, which is a continued improvement. So it's a long winded saying, we like both markets and the balance sheets in great shape here today with, if you deduct the $120 million-ish of acquisitions under contract from the $220 million of cash we had at year-end and you pro forma for the $500 million bond issuance we're sitting on about $600 million of cash today, which gives us good liquidity to fund external growth as we get through the rest of the year.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: And then, I guess, just second question about real estate taxes. I know in the MD&A section here in the 10-Q, you sort of talked about real estate taxes staying relatively consistent, up kind of about 5%. But are you just seeing any relief in any market a
componenttext: And then, I guess, just second question about real estate taxes. I know in the MD&A section here in the 10-Q, you sort of talked about real estate taxes staying relatively consistent, up kind of about 5%. But are you just seeing any relief in any market and as you kind of look forward, when might that start to tail off of a bit?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Relief is not what I would consider what we're seeing in real estate taxes today. So we do expect property taxes to grow around 5% this year. If you look back over prior years, that's reasonably consistent with what we've seen. I do think that there's an
componenttext: Relief is not what I would consider what we're seeing in real estate taxes today. So we do expect property taxes to grow around 5% this year. If you look back over prior years, that's reasonably consistent with what we've seen. I do think that there's an element of catch up to cash flow earlier in the cycle associated with the real estate values that we're seeing. And so, in certain markets, could we see a benefit going forward as incomes have maybe come down in some of our more supply impacted markets, it's really possible, but we're not seeing that in any real quality at this point.

componenttext: Yes, I touched on this a little bit. There's no question that the overall Internet paid search environment continues to get more competitive. But like I said earlier, we're seeing good demand response for our brand term online and we've continued to push there and like what we're seeing.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: This is Ryan. Just circling back sort of on the fifth-generation reinvestment program, are you able to quantify for us the total capital investment we can anticipate in '19? And maybe the number of stores that are involved in that program alone?
componenttext: This is Ryan. Just circling back sort of on the fifth-generation reinvestment program, are you able to quantify for us the total capital investment we can anticipate in '19? And maybe the number of stores that are involved in that program alone?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: So again, it's a rollout that we've now been testing, say for the last 1.5 years to 2 years. So through 2018, we began to test in a number of different markets what we call our property tomorrow for platform, which is taking number of key elements from ou
componenttext:
So again, it's a rollout that we've now been testing, say for the last 1.5 years to 2 years. So through 2018, we began to test in a number of different markets what we call our property tomorrow for platform, which is taking number of key elements from our fifth-generation product and overlaying it into the existing assets. Some of its somewhat straightforward, meaning it's enhanced, signage, updated, [ paining schemes ]. We're also optimizing things like water usage through landscaping improvements, utilities around LEDs, changing the office environment because today's world environment with our new Web Champ 2 platform we've gone completely paperless. We don't need filing cabinets anymore. We've got more space to create a better customer environment. 
So all those things have played through quite well in the properties that we've tested. Thus far, which totals, say less than 75 or so assets that we tested in a number of different markets through 2018. So this year, we're moonlighting the rollout with all the feedback and the reaction that we've gotten from the customers, employees, et cetera. And it's starting here on the West Coast. We're likely to touch anywhere from say 100 to 150 properties in the next 2 to 3 quarters here in California specifically, and then, we'll be rolling it into a number of different markets literally for the next few years as we touch the entire portfolio. 
In 2019, the cost tied to this is plus or minus about $100 million. And it wouldn't be surprising over the next few years, we spent $0.5 billion or more as we roll this entire plan out. And we like what we're seeing so far. So the properties that have been retooled to this new standard are seeing some residual benefit in a number of ways. It's still early in that regard, but we like what we're seeing. And we think it's really another way to amplify and enhance not only the curb appeal and the brand itself that resonates incredibly well to consumers, but it matches all the things that we doing on an online basis as well. So again, it's a program we've got a lot of focus on and we're likely to see fair amount of capital in subsequent years  that's going to be dedicated to this effort.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: That's helpful color. Can you maybe translate what have you in your test market spent on a per square foot basis? Or what do you anticipate spending on a per square foot basis?
componenttext: That's helpful color. Can you maybe translate what have you in your test market spent on a per square foot basis? Or what do you anticipate spending on a per square foot basis?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, it's too -- I wouldn't point you that direction yet because it can vary. Some properties, it can be what I would call, a lighter rebranding because it may not need as many components and then other properties that can be more thorough or we're touchi
componenttext: Yes, it's too -- I wouldn't point you that direction yet because it can vary. Some properties, it can be what I would call, a lighter rebranding because it may not need as many components and then other properties that can be more thorough or we're touching a number of different components of the asset itself. So I wouldn't point you to a specific number on a per asset basis yet.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, I mean obviously, you had some very new assets that you recently developed and you're not going to be reinvesting in those. What is the total percentage of your portfolio that you would like touch roughly speaking?
componenttext: Okay. And then, I mean obviously, you had some very new assets that you recently developed and you're not going to be reinvesting in those. What is the total percentage of your portfolio that you would like touch roughly speaking?

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well,  ultimately, in its purest form, we would mainline or lift the entire portfolio to elements of again, that's new standard that we're rolling out as we speak. So that's why I mentioned this could take several years. So we do have what we would charac
componenttext: Well,  ultimately, in its purest form, we would mainline or lift the entire portfolio to elements of again, that's new standard that we're rolling out as we speak. So that's why I mentioned this could take several years. So we do have what we would characterize as 5 generations of product. So 2,400 locations, some of which have been in our hands for 30, 40 plus years back. So those may need in some cases heavier levels of, again, elements of the program that I talked to and some may not. But it's going to be on a case-by-case basis the amount of enhancement that we're going to do property-to-property. So again, what we'll continue to do is moderate and choose assets that make sense to given the early phases of the program and then we'll roll it out overtime. And ultimately, at a certain point, we'll get to most of the portfolio.

headline: Public Storage, Q1 2019 Earnings Call, May 02, 2019
