componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Jeremy Metz of BMO Capital markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Joe, just wondering if you can comment on the revenue growth here, the 1.9%. Just wondering, how that faired relative to your expectations? And then as we look at their trajectory, supply coming on here, the softness in demand, you guys have spoken about
componenttext: Joe, just wondering if you can comment on the revenue growth here, the 1.9%. Just wondering, how that faired relative to your expectations? And then as we look at their trajectory, supply coming on here, the softness in demand, you guys have spoken about would would be off base to expect it to trend back lower from here and in the 2020?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jeremy, I think first of all, certainly we were encouraged by the fact that we saw another step up in our revenue growth so we have been seeing acceleration, if you look at the quarter-to-quarter performance sequentially over the last few quarters. T
componenttext:
Yes, Jeremy, I think first of all, certainly we were encouraged by the fact that we saw another step up in our revenue growth so we have been seeing acceleration, if you look at the quarter-to-quarter performance sequentially over the last few quarters. Tom just reviewed,one of the important ingredients and unique capabilities that we've got relative to leveraging the power of our brand, the initiatives we've got around customer search efforts and the things that we do operationally that continue to navigate what clearly continues to be market to market, in some cases a heavy level of competition that is and could be with us for some period of time. 
We've been now in this band, say the 1% to 2% of revenue range, you can look at our predicted metrics going into Q3 kind of puts us in that same range more or less. The things that we continue to use and drive relative to the capabilities, however, are encouraging because again, quarter-to-quarter, we're unlocking and using different tools and different levers to continue to drive the level of activity, customer acquisition and things that we can do to operate, again, in some cases, a very competitive market. 
Supply, as I mentioned, is going to be with us. This year, our tracking points to again another of about $5 billion worth of deliveries. We think, in 2020, it's going to taper down a bit, maybe 10% to 15%, but you can't ignore the fact that it's still heavy. It is shifting and we've talked about that for the last few quarters from some of the more heavily impacted markets that got hit early in the cycle to markets now that we got even more focus on knowing that we're going to have to, again, ramp up our efforts to compete with new supply, whether it's in a market like Miami, Boston, Portland, Oregon. So we're keeping it a very close eye, and again, getting geared up to make sure we are as effective there as we've been over the last few quarters, dealing with these other markets that have been hit hard. But the good news is, the resiliency of the business overall is strong. Our customer base and encourages us because we are seeing really no different behavior. Customer continues to be quite sticky, and again, it talks to the overall resiliency, coupled with the fact that our own capabilities of scale, the brand and the technological tools that we are continuing to develop our working well.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. So it sounds pretty fair to lot of it internal change of view on supply, if I heard you correct. I mean sort of in line with what you've been forecasting, is that fair?
componenttext: Yes. So it sounds pretty fair to lot of it internal change of view on supply, if I heard you correct. I mean sort of in line with what you've been forecasting, is that fair?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: That's fair. And again, there's -- without question, kind of points to on the flip side, what we've been seeing on the acquisition front, there is a growing old is out there that are taking product to market, they've got more sensible expectations relativ
componenttext: That's fair. And again, there's -- without question, kind of points to on the flip side, what we've been seeing on the acquisition front, there is a growing old is out there that are taking product to market, they've got more sensible expectations relative to exit values. So we're seeing some good opportunities evolve on that end of the spectrum, but at the same time, many developers still look at this product as a very attractive product to be built, whether it is to own shorter-term -- short-term or long-term and or just flip because in some cases, they can make a return see where an environment where we are seeing markets oversupply. So again, we're dealing with these levels of deliveries as an industry, we haven't seen before. And as we all know, it can take anywhere from 2, 3 or 4 years in many cases for these deliveries to be stabilized until they are. you, which is a competitive factor you have to deal with.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: All right. And second from me and you just touch on a little, but if I look at where you are buying in terms of price per pound and as I look at where you are able to do the expansions and the developments and even the yields you've talked about in the pa
componenttext: All right. And second from me and you just touch on a little, but if I look at where you are buying in terms of price per pound and as I look at where you are able to do the expansions and the developments and even the yields you've talked about in the past, it seems like a pretty good trade-off here. So just wondering what if anything is holding you back from doing more development and the expansions just given that obviously capital is an issue. Is it just human capital, is that their availability of sides are expansion potential that as you look at it?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean there's a few things in the mix there, Jeremy. So one of the things that we've talked about is the fact that we've got a pool of assets that in some cases we've owned for 3 and 4 decades that continually become candidates for potential expans
componenttext: Well, I mean there's a few things in the mix there, Jeremy. So one of the things that we've talked about is the fact that we've got a pool of assets that in some cases we've owned for 3 and 4 decades that continually become candidates for potential expansion. Now you can look at that and say, okay, just go do it all at once or tackle it at 1 time, but property to the property, city to city, you have to work through a variety of different entitlements, processes. In some cases, you can't make any changes and others, you have to go into negotiations or processes that could take months, years in some cases so you've got that factor at hand. And then the other thing that we are very cognizant of is the impact that any expansion create an existing revenue stream on a particular asset. So you've got to calibrate around all those factors. The things that we've been able to do is identify and leverage the skills that we've got in our development team into that effort. So you've seen on a proportionate basis, as we stand today, about 64% of our overall development pipeline is tied into redevelopment. Now the thing that has been trending down over the last few quarters, we haven't seen as many land opportunities that have been attractive, but there is some level of similarity with what's going on with land as it relates to what we're seeing on just pure acquisitions, meaning, there are a broader pool of owners out there that we're seeing that are coming to us and saying, hey, I've got a piece of property. I thought I was going to take it through full entitlements or maybe it's already entitled, but I'm not going to take that next step to develop. So we're encouraged by that and the development teams are working hard to pull even more of those opportunities one by one particularly if they not only makes sense in the near term, but long-term as well. So we've got, I think, some good opportunities in that realm going into the cycle that we're seeing ahead of us. So thanks, Jimmy. I think we're going to take the next question.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: First question, Tom, back to the move-in rents. So 1381 square foot in the quarter, higher by about $0.22 a square foot. Historically, the seasonal uptick is a little bit greater from 1Q to 2Q and then, rents tend to decline are the seasonally adjusted ba
componenttext: First question, Tom, back to the move-in rents. So 1381 square foot in the quarter, higher by about $0.22 a square foot. Historically, the seasonal uptick is a little bit greater from 1Q to 2Q and then, rents tend to decline are the seasonally adjusted basis throughout the off peak season. Is the more muted increase this quarter indicative of the pressure we're seeing across the system and would you expect the same seasonal patterns to hold throughout the balance of the year or have you made some changes to pricing our or otherwise that may cause seasonal trends to change a little bit. I was wondering if you could speak to that.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure. I did comment earlier around move-in rates being down 4% year-over-year, which certainly takes into consideration seasonality of our rental rate as we go through. I think generally speaking, you're going to continue to see the seasonality as oc
componenttext: Yes, sure. I did comment earlier around move-in rates being down 4% year-over-year, which certainly takes into consideration seasonality of our rental rate as we go through. I think generally speaking, you're going to continue to see the seasonality as occupancy and our move-in traffic is higher in the summer months than it is as we get into the fall and into the winter months. So seasonality is not going to change. But we did use lower move-in rates in the second quarter as one of the levers to drive volumes. So to give you an example, Miami, which is a tougher market, that Joe highlighted where we're seeing new supply impact operations there. We were successful in driving move-in traffic there. Move-ins were up year-over-year despite the incremental new supply, but we did utilize rate on an advertising. So rates were down, call it 7%, 8% on move-ins in Miami in the second quarter. So there's no question that there is a rate pressure where there is new supply and we're also utilizing rates to drive volumes in some of those markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then, as you push through rate increases to existing customers during the quarter and usually, May, June and July are big months for that, any push back or change from customers or change in the rent increase program throughout the peak season a
componenttext: Okay. And then, as you push through rate increases to existing customers during the quarter and usually, May, June and July are big months for that, any push back or change from customers or change in the rent increase program throughout the peak season as a results started to come in? And maybe in a market like Miami where there is some rate pressure, and you have customers move-in in at lower initial rates, is there any difference in sort of the rate increase program in those markets and in those stores relative to the balance of the portfolio?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. The first around just performance of existing tenants and their willingness to continue to remain customers post a rate increase to the rental rates and that's very consistent. In fact, trending positively as we've gone through the quarter. So we di
componenttext: Sure. The first around just performance of existing tenants and their willingness to continue to remain customers post a rate increase to the rental rates and that's very consistent. In fact, trending positively as we've gone through the quarter. So we disclosed in the 10-Q move, out volumes were down, which is what drove the increase in occupancy throughout the quarter, average up 20 basis points actually finished up 50 basis points in the quarter. So while move-ins were flat, move-outs were down and that's because that existing tenant base is performing quite well. The existing tenants are exhibiting great dynamics. If you look at delinquency numbers, that are supported by wage growth, the great labor market, so lots of good things happening there for existing tenants and we continue to see that throughout the portfolio. In terms of rate strategies in different markets, certainly, what's going on with the move-in dynamics and move-out dynamics within a local market will impact of our strategies for existing kind of rate increases, I'm not going to go into details their, but certainly those are some of the factors considered. In terms of how things are trending into July, are down again in July. So again, very consistent trends.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019

componenttext: Your next question comes from Ronald Kamdem from Morgan Stanley.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just 2 quick ones from me. One, just going back to sort of the move-in volumes that you touched on, given the elevated marketing spend, the question really is, is there any change in the profile of the customer that's moving in today maybe versus a year a
componenttext: Just 2 quick ones from me. One, just going back to sort of the move-in volumes that you touched on, given the elevated marketing spend, the question really is, is there any change in the profile of the customer that's moving in today maybe versus a year ago? So said another way, is it more millennials or is it is there no discernible trend on that? And sort of a follow-up to that would also be, when you think about the returns that you're getting on the marketing spend, is that something that remains compelling where we could even see an increase even from these levels?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ron, I'll take the first part of that and hand it over to Tom to talk about the second part of your question. So from a customers' standpoint, I wouldn't point you at anything that shifted material -- materially whether you link into becoming a diffe
componenttext: Yes, Ron, I'll take the first part of that and hand it over to Tom to talk about the second part of your question. So from a customers' standpoint, I wouldn't point you at anything that shifted material -- materially whether you link into becoming a different type of customer. The good news is they are becoming good customers. And there is no both statistical and/or trend that we could point to that says that that's any different than what we've seen with other generations as they age into the kinds of things that drives them to take down and storage unit. So many of the very similar and same drivers that have affected by our generation so to now affecting million dollars years if you could even argue, there is an end of the day, as we speak today, maybe fewer homeowners out there that are much more sensitized to the cost of owning a home that they are looking at smaller apartments. They are making trade-offs of keeping there is a turnoff in lower alternatives in storage. We are seeing good traction. We're doing a lot of surveys relative to the types of customers that are coming into us, and again, no change there. In fact, we are continually encouraged that the data to is evolving into a very powerful type of consumer that we see driving our business just as other generations have. Tom, you want to take the next part?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. Yes, the second part of the question was on marketing spend and the returns we're seeing associated with it. In the comments I made earlier, we're seeing good returns. It is a process here that's managed very dynamically at the level and local level
componenttext: Sure. Yes, the second part of the question was on marketing spend and the returns we're seeing associated with it. In the comments I made earlier, we're seeing good returns. It is a process here that's managed very dynamically at the level and local level. We're adjusting our bids based on the demand response we're receiving and the returns we're receiving. The returns have been good. And so we're pushing ever harder on that lever as we move through 2019 and we'll continue to, but we'll also continue to monitor that to ensure that we're getting the return that we seek, but the returns are good there and we like that strategy.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Great. I don't know if that was 2 questions, but the last quick one was just on, just looking at the West Coast markets, clearly, some of the strongest performers there. I think you've talked historically about limited supply, but maybe can you talk about
componenttext: Great. I don't know if that was 2 questions, but the last quick one was just on, just looking at the West Coast markets, clearly, some of the strongest performers there. I think you've talked historically about limited supply, but maybe can you talk about what they sort of the existing tenants there and sort of if there is any rent fatigue given that it's been a couple of years of rate increases or you're not seeing any noticeable trends?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: No noticeable trends there. The difference between some of those West Coast markets is when I talked about Miami and move-in rates being lower, Los Angeles move-in rates were higher in the quarter. So there's different trends going on in those different m
componenttext: No noticeable trends there. The difference between some of those West Coast markets is when I talked about Miami and move-in rates being lower, Los Angeles move-in rates were higher in the quarter. So there's different trends going on in those different markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: And just to add to that, from a supply standpoint, you're correct. The West Coast basically shielded from the amount of volume from a supply standpoint. We really don't see that changing because of lack of land inventory entitlement, complexity, Portland
componenttext: And just to add to that, from a supply standpoint, you're correct. The West Coast basically shielded from the amount of volume from a supply standpoint. We really don't see that changing because of lack of land inventory entitlement, complexity, Portland is under stress right now, but outside of Portland we feel really good about the competitive arena on the West Coast.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose from Citigroup.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose from Citigroup.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your acquisition opportunities are still elevated, I'm just wondering if you could talk a little bit about what you're seeing in terms of opportunities that are still lease up versus stabilized more lease of coming available to you that are interesting or
componenttext: Your acquisition opportunities are still elevated, I'm just wondering if you could talk a little bit about what you're seeing in terms of opportunities that are still lease up versus stabilized more lease of coming available to you that are interesting or maybe just some color on the overall acquisition outlook?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. There's a variety of different reasons we've seen the uptick in acquisition volume. It's included some owners that have come to us directly. They haven't taken their properties out to market, whether it is because, again, they are under some level of
componenttext: Yes. There's a variety of different reasons we've seen the uptick in acquisition volume. It's included some owners that have come to us directly. They haven't taken their properties out to market, whether it is because, again, they are under some level of duress and/or they've just made a decision that time to exit either a specific property or whatever size platform they may have. And with that, we've seen a variety of different occupancy levels. We continue to look at properties that range anywhere from either newly developed and/or fully stabilized. I can point you to we did a 4 building acquisition in the Miami area. Each of the buildings had different levels of occupancy, 1  or 2 or more stabilized than the other 2 that have been more recently delivered to the market. So there's a range there. And we are seeing and hearing that there are -- there's a lot of activity out there relative to particularly within the brokerage community, brokers are being asked to come and do valuations for orders in the last quarter, we saw a lot of inquiries coming into us with a gain a full range of different times situations, all of which we consider. We are in the we take a look at. So we really haven't changed on our end the way that we continue to analyze and look at returns that we can get from these investments. But we're seeing our sellers that are far more agreeable and more anxious to make a decision to exit. And some, again, have gone to maybe clear and more evident levels of stress. Others, again, have just made a more rational decision and said it's time and a good point in the cycle to consider an exit as maybe a level or a price that 1  or 2 years ago was much more elevated and we wouldn't have engaged from a conversation and today we are. So, as we reported, we've done more transaction volume this year than we did all of last year. We've got about $87 million under contract and we are seeing again, connectivity in some of the situations that are playing through.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: I mean, just to follow up on that, do you think -- I mean, you mentioned supply, the dollar amount of deliveries coming down next year, I guess, most of that is probably financed and under construction. Do you have a sense of just looking out further than
componenttext: I mean, just to follow up on that, do you think -- I mean, you mentioned supply, the dollar amount of deliveries coming down next year, I guess, most of that is probably financed and under construction. Do you have a sense of just looking out further than that, I mean, do you think that lenders are now starting to rethink the availability of capital to the industry and we can start seeing supply numbers really start to drop off pretty quickly?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's tough to predict. There's a number of different conflicting drivers that are still in the mix. So there are still a lot of investors, private equity and otherwise that are coming into the sector that haven't been in self-storage before. So the
componenttext: Yes, that's tough to predict. There's a number of different conflicting drivers that are still in the mix. So there are still a lot of investors, private equity and otherwise that are coming into the sector that haven't been in self-storage before. So there is some fuel that comes from that. As I mentioned, there is still development returns some individual developers say it is still a good reward risk balance. So they may launch and still may get the funding to do with. On the flip side, I don't disagree with your comments that I think more and more renters are becoming more stringent and the way that they are in and basically putting lending packages out to developers. So hopefully, that creates some level of added discipline we haven't seen, but again, there's still fuel out there. And like I said, we're sensing that there is likely to be in that 10% to 15% stage or shift down going from this year to next year, but that is still puts you north of $4 billion of deliveries. That is a lot of product. So we are keeping a very close eye and we are not confused about how it impacts certain markets as I mentioned earlier, and the good news is we feel more and more encouraged that we've got the playbook to continue to navigate around it.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa of Evercore.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa of Evercore.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: I guess, most of my questions have been asked at this point. Just in terms of business customers, any sort of change or anything new that you're seeing on on that front as customers kind of looking to come in to the self-storage product?
componenttext: I guess, most of my questions have been asked at this point. Just in terms of business customers, any sort of change or anything new that you're seeing on on that front as customers kind of looking to come in to the self-storage product?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Steve, I couldn't say something materially different. We have and we'll continue to embrace, I would say, a healthy level of business related customers that ranges anywhere from something as landscaper or a local contractor to maybe in today's world, some
componenttext: Steve, I couldn't say something materially different. We have and we'll continue to embrace, I would say, a healthy level of business related customers that ranges anywhere from something as landscaper or a local contractor to maybe in today's world, some customers that are playing into, again, this last mile distribution, focus and again, different types of entrepreneurs and/or even more sizable companies that do feel sensible to have something in close proximity to another facility or a customer base, et cetera. It can range from a percentage standpoint, property to property, anywhere from easily say, 10%, 15%, 20% to sometimes much higher, again, depending on the location of a particular property. So there is again, I would say, a consistent and good amount of activity that we see just from distressed customers and we embrace and cater to them just as much as we do to individual and consumers.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, just 1 other question. You've done very, very large facilities like up in the Bronx, several thousand storage facilities and units. Are there any kind of lessons you've learned off of from some of these? Is this kind of the economic ret
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, just 1 other question. You've done very, very large facilities like up in the Bronx, several thousand storage facilities and units. Are there any kind of lessons you've learned off of from some of these? Is this kind of the economic returns out? How do you sort of look at that you've done and kind of the pace of those going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Well, we certainly have done more than We've got now several facilities that are closed and in fact, Jersey City is now larger than Jersey City, our largest current system, our current property in our system, about 4200 units. We opened that just a little
componenttext: Well, we certainly have done more than We've got now several facilities that are closed and in fact, Jersey City is now larger than Jersey City, our largest current system, our current property in our system, about 4200 units. We opened that just a little over 2 years ago. Today, it's nearly 90% occupied. So what leads us to and how we basically place design and configure something of that magnitude in A market is, we use a lot of analytics. We look at the level of competitive activity and then we take a lot of day-to-day metrics we see in like properties that we may own and particularly decide how big to go. But there's no question, the bigger facilities like this create another level of complexity that again, we have to tune our operational teams again, handle. So Jersey City, it wouldn't be unusual, for instance, as we fill that property up to have 40 to 50 move-ins literally on a weekend. And if you bench that against kind of a traditional size storage facility, that might be a volume we see in a month. So you've got to have a team of people running the asset, you've got a different level, you've got different complexity relative to the design of the facility itself, number of elevators, the way the floor to floor configuration works on unit sizes. And with the amenities though however, with these bigger facilities, customers love them. And again, they are very efficient, very customer service-oriented because we are running, again, larger teams that are clearly accessible and at the counter and are open all day long, and again, we are looking and expanding their plan from where it makes sense in many different parts of the country. So that too, if a character that some of the activity that we're seeing on the acquisition side, na√Øvely, a number of orders or developers have come into the business thinking okay, it's a good idea to just go as big as we can. We'll go into the city, if we were thinking about building a 50,000 or 75,000 square-foot product, we'll go to 100,000 or 125,000 or even in some cases, larger than that without the skill, knowledge and capability to actually run a facility of that size and it's not unusual and we see it time and again, where a facility like that can get to 50% or 60% occupied and it just stalls. Because if you don't have the ability to drive volume, understand how to cater to existing customers, if you haven't got the right technology capabilities of our day-to-day customer, you are going to flatline. Now that creates in many cases, a good opportunity for us and we are seeing more and more.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from Eric shingle of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Your next question comes from Eric shingle of Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: I just like to circle back on the marketing expense. How exactly do you calculate the return on investment for the increase in marketing and how much of the increase in marketing and adjusting the increase in click rates online and just how much you had t
componenttext: I just like to circle back on the marketing expense. How exactly do you calculate the return on investment for the increase in marketing and how much of the increase in marketing and adjusting the increase in click rates online and just how much you had to pay to Google?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. Without getting into too much detail as to how returns are calculated, it's a pretty simple concept about what the customer worth to us and what are the acquisition costs all in, which it takes to acquire that customer, and ultimately get them to mo
componenttext:
Sure. Without getting into too much detail as to how returns are calculated, it's a pretty simple concept about what the customer worth to us and what are the acquisition costs all in, which it takes to acquire that customer, and ultimately get them to move-in. And so, we have the ability in today's world online to track and understand much more about our customers and to be able to do that, those bids much more dynamically than done in the past. So we can monitor those returns on a customer by customer bases and a keyword by keyword basis. 
In terms of the overall cost and the competitiveness online, there's no question that we're not only one pushing on this lever. Some of our traditional operating competitors are pushing on that lever as well and probably seeing similar good returns. So we'd expect that to continue. In addition, we have other folks, both regional operators as well as storage operators and other types of folks that are bidding on keywords and driving the cost per click higher. On the last call, I noted that cost per click for similar positioning was probably up double digits, maybe call it teens, it's north of that today.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful color. Just a quick follow-up question. I just noticed in your Q that you expect to spend roughly $1.1 billion on investments over the next year or so. That's actually down from $1.4 billion last quarter and so your comments have kind
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful color. Just a quick follow-up question. I just noticed in your Q that you expect to spend roughly $1.1 billion on investments over the next year or so. That's actually down from $1.4 billion last quarter and so your comments have kind of imply that you're seeing an expanded menu of investment opportunities, but I guess, you're not budgeting as much. Is there a reason for the disconnect?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: No, I think if you're looking at liquidity and capital resources analysis, we highlight that we have capital resources of about $1.1 billion, but then when you walk through the uses, a lot of them haven't been identified. So one of the clear usage is our
componenttext: No, I think if you're looking at liquidity and capital resources analysis, we highlight that we have capital resources of about $1.1 billion, but then when you walk through the uses, a lot of them haven't been identified. So one of the clear usage is our development pipeline, which as it stands today, we have about $329 million of cash required to complete that existing pipeline. But as Joe mentioned, we'll be adding properties to that pipeline over time, but we'd expect to spend that $330 million roughly over the next 18 months. In addition to that, we have acquisitions that are on contract at quarter end that Joe highlighted earlier, $87 million and we are seeing more opportunities there. So we expect more acquisitions as we move through the year. But the $1.1 billion is really our capital resources, which are the cash on hand that we have, the revolver capacity as well as retain cash flow over the next 12 months.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Got you. So the revolver capacity is kind of the limitation on that number?
componenttext: Got you. So the revolver capacity is kind of the limitation on that number?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: No, I mean, we could go out, like we did in the second quarter, and raise additional capital if there is opportunities that. In an environment right now it is pretty attractive from a rate standpoint. We could issue 10-year bonds today, touch under 3%, pr
componenttext: No, I mean, we could go out, like we did in the second quarter, and raise additional capital if there is opportunities that. In an environment right now it is pretty attractive from a rate standpoint. We could issue 10-year bonds today, touch under 3%, prefers are probably around 5%, maybe a touch under 5%. So attractive Capital Markets that finance incremental capital needs over the next 12 months.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just on the third party management platform, can we just hear I guess, how it's performing? And then, since you are being so inquisitive, you are obviously talking to potential sellers. Is third-party management brought up in those conversations if you ge
componenttext: Just on the third party management platform, can we just hear I guess, how it's performing? And then, since you are being so inquisitive, you are obviously talking to potential sellers. Is third-party management brought up in those conversations if you get a potential reluctant seller that you could manage maybe just some color there.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: There are a number of things that we continue to see and learn through our entrance into the third-party management business. So the program continues to grow. Our backlog still being the backlog as we expected will take time to turn into actual openings
componenttext: There are a number of things that we continue to see and learn through our entrance into the third-party management business. So the program continues to grow. Our backlog still being the backlog as we expected will take time to turn into actual openings because it's primarily oriented towards either pre-and/or in development opportunities. We've now got -- this year, we've added about 23 properties to the program. In total, our entire program is 62 properties, but we are seeing and learning very different elements of the business as a whole, including a number of orders that may have a range of different horizons to ownership, whether it is more limited in time or it could be long-standing. So with that, are going to come variety of different potential opportunities. The other thing that is not surprising, but there is a bit of activity around just orders that are looking for a change as well. So we're seeing some activity tied to that, whether it is underway public third-party management platform more private one. So again, we're seeing good opportunities there. we are able to balance and now, with the team built internally, drive activity into even more markets that we want to grow from a scale. At the present standpoint. So we've got more out about activity tied to that, and again, as I mentioned, a variety of different situations that could be interesting over time.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay, that's helpful. And then just to circle back with the acquisitions, I don't know if you characterized what you bought in Q2 and then what you have teed up in Q3, but just roughly, the ones that are stabilized versus those in lease up, it maybe just
componenttext: Okay, that's helpful. And then just to circle back with the acquisitions, I don't know if you characterized what you bought in Q2 and then what you have teed up in Q3, but just roughly, the ones that are stabilized versus those in lease up, it maybe just the rents, what kind of upside do you expect in the next properties? Are they stabilized? And what type of growth entrance can we expect?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: It's a lie, I talked about this a little earlier. It's a mix. We've got property to property a variety of different either occupancy or/and stabilized revenue components to the assets themselves. Some of them in place for a number of years, some are newer
componenttext: It's a lie, I talked about this a little earlier. It's a mix. We've got property to property a variety of different either occupancy or/and stabilized revenue components to the assets themselves. Some of them in place for a number of years, some are newer. And again, a typical, again, trajectory that the property go through. You might see a quick lease up, but then from a maturity standpoint, the revenue doesn't stabilize for years beyond that until you look at, again, a tenant database that becomes more mature. So we're looking and seeing good returns relative to the investment we are making into the pool of assets that we continue to buy and it's a collection of all of those factors. So again, the other thing I mentioned, we like it never spending more time with a number of situations we haven't seen over the last couple of years. So the acquisition team is out of focus on those as we speak.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Steve, maybe I just point you to the 10-Q where we break out on Page 48 what the occupancy and rate numbers are for those acquisitions. And you can see that 2019 acquisitions at 78.2% occupancy some lease up within some of the acquisitions that enjoy spea
componenttext: Steve, maybe I just point you to the 10-Q where we break out on Page 48 what the occupancy and rate numbers are for those acquisitions. And you can see that 2019 acquisitions at 78.2% occupancy some lease up within some of the acquisitions that enjoy speaking to and likely rent growth and those lease up as well.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019

componenttext: Yes, most things have been answered as well, but just wondering what was the average effective rate increase that you were able to pass through to existing customers this year?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: I would say trends have been very consistent there. As we talked about in the past that does move throughout the year both in terms of quantity as well as rate based on what we're seeing in our markets. The averages are around that kind of high single dig
componenttext: I would say trends have been very consistent there. As we talked about in the past that does move throughout the year both in terms of quantity as well as rate based on what we're seeing in our markets. The averages are around that kind of high single digits, 10% type number, but no real change there from a strategy standpoint.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim from SunTrust.
componenttext: Your next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim from SunTrust.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: You're debt to preferred equity ratio is about 33%. Do you have a view on longer term what that mix should look like?
componenttext: You're debt to preferred equity ratio is about 33%. Do you have a view on longer term what that mix should look like?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Longer term, we said we're committed to both of those markets tools. They both provide great attributes. We thought it made a lot of sense back in the fall of 2017, they really add debt to the playbook in order to finance acquisitions and really gives us
componenttext: Longer term, we said we're committed to both of those markets tools. They both provide great attributes. We thought it made a lot of sense back in the fall of 2017, they really add debt to the playbook in order to finance acquisitions and really gives us access to a deeper institutional pool of capital that allows us to raise more in a shorter period of time to fund acquisition opportunities. And so, as we look at those 2 markets, I would expect that we continue to utilize both. As you highlight right now, about 33% of that is debt and about 67% of it is preferred stock. We don't have a particular target where we're going to target a specific number, but we would expect that will utilize both going forward.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: But in the current environment, does one look more appealing than other?
componenttext: But in the current environment, does one look more appealing than other?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Frankly, both look pretty good right now. The gap between a 10-year bond and a preferred stock offering today is around 200 basis points, which is pretty consistent with the post crisis averages. So pretty consistent. We obviously just raised $500 million
componenttext: Frankly, both look pretty good right now. The gap between a 10-year bond and a preferred stock offering today is around 200 basis points, which is pretty consistent with the post crisis averages. So pretty consistent. We obviously just raised $500 million of 10-year bonds in April. We redeemed 6% preferred because they were in the body and the end of June. As we go through the year, we've got 5 and 7 8s preferred that are callable in December, but certainly are in the money as we look at them right now. So we expect certainly to be an opportunity to add preferred stock to the capital stack as we go through the year in addition to what we did with bonds earlier.

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And just going back to the advertising question. You said you are getting a good return on advertising spend. I'm sure the utility curve to everything, right. Where do you think we are in the utility curve of getting a good return on advertising?
componenttext: Okay. And just going back to the advertising question. You said you are getting a good return on advertising spend. I'm sure the utility curve to everything, right. Where do you think we are in the utility curve of getting a good return on advertising?

headline: Public Storage, Q2 2019 Earnings Call, Jul 31, 2019
componenttextpreview: We are still seeing good returns. So you have seen us increase our spend throughout the period. There are some keywords that certainly are at levels that we feel comfortable with where we are and there is on those that we can increase further. And it will
componenttext: We are still seeing good returns. So you have seen us increase our spend throughout the period. There are some keywords that certainly are at levels that we feel comfortable with where we are and there is on those that we can increase further. And it will depend on the traffic we see in our local markets as we dynamically evaluate that what returns have been good and that is very much a decision that is at the very local and granular level, not at the aggregate level.
