headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just in the context of where we're at, what are your views on supply for across your California?
componenttext: Just in the context of where we're at, what are your views on supply for across your California?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: California itself. So, okay, so for the most part California is in very good shape. Now going south to north, there's parts of San Diego County, we're keeping a close eye on to because of some elevated deliveries in some of outer markets within San Diego
componenttext: California itself. So, okay, so for the most part California is in very good shape. Now going south to north, there's parts of San Diego County, we're keeping a close eye on to because of some elevated deliveries in some of outer markets within San Diego County. Orange County and L.A. County for the most part are pretty, I would say, inactive from a new development standpoint, primarily because there's very little land available and it's very expensive if, in fact, we're able to find anything if you're regular on the L.A. metro market, may be a little more activity out in the Inland Empire. Then you open into the Bay Area again, San Francisco -- South San Francisco, again, no worries there. A little bit of heavy activity in the San Jose market that we're keeping a close eye on, but again, not a big amount of inventory on a percentage of existing base. So we continue to see in our own development pipeline in these markets where we've really had the opportunity to take existing assets from the most part and do some pretty meaningful expansions. And again, repeating what I just said around the traction we're getting from that activity, the expansions that we're doing are leasing up really well. So we're very pleased by that, seeing very good traction, and again, for the most part, I would say California is in pretty good shape.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Appreciate that color. And second one from me. I want to go back to the move-out rates. Tom, you mentioned the 60 basis points here historically or even just looking back to past few years at least you've had a rent roll down, which makes sense in the con
componenttext: Appreciate that color. And second one from me. I want to go back to the move-out rates. Tom, you mentioned the 60 basis points here historically or even just looking back to past few years at least you've had a rent roll down, which makes sense in the context of rising rents and the in-place bump traction. That's now flipped here in the past 2 quarters. So just wondering is that more reflection of the overall rents you're bringing customers in at or is that a reflection at all in strategy shift and how aggressive you are on pushing in place rents just given the widening spread to market there?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I think it's largely the fact that as folks move-in at lower rates, the move-in -- move-outs are coming out at lower rates, that's the biggest driver there. No real shifting strategy on existing tenant rate increases. We talked about modestly lengthening
componenttext: I think it's largely the fact that as folks move-in at lower rates, the move-in -- move-outs are coming out at lower rates, that's the biggest driver there. No real shifting strategy on existing tenant rate increases. We talked about modestly lengthening length of stays, which is contributed to contribution from existing tenant rate increases, but no real shifting strategy there. So the decrease about rental rates is driven by move-ins coming at lower rates.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of Citi.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I wanted to ask you and your you talk about kind of the appeal essentially the fifth generation products that are coming to market. And I'm just wondering is there an opportunity to take advantage of what apparently still very strong pricing for older sta
componenttext: I wanted to ask you and your you talk about kind of the appeal essentially the fifth generation products that are coming to market. And I'm just wondering is there an opportunity to take advantage of what apparently still very strong pricing for older stabilized assets, maybe in your portfolio and in assets in some of the growth markets you talked about earlier within your facilities?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, sure, Smedes. So a couple of different areas to talk to there. So first of all, I think it's well known that one of the benefits of the product type itself is you can go through decades of use on our assets and they can be every bit as vibrant in tod
componenttext:
Yes, sure, Smedes. So a couple of different areas to talk to there. So first of all, I think it's well known that one of the benefits of the product type itself is you can go through decades of use on our assets and they can be every bit as vibrant in today's world and even more so in many cases than they were originally developed. So is variable obsolescence that we're seeing anywhere in the portfolio. What we're doing though to actually continue to enhance even some of those revenue streams and again, amplify performance property to property with some of our older assets is a program we've talked a little bit about, which is a Property of Tomorrow program where we're going through and putting to your point what we would call fifth-generation attributes into many of these assets where we can, again, enhance the curb appeal of the asset through more modern paint schemes, signage or improving the office and customer areas that align with some of the technology issue or technology strategies that we've had or at this point going through California from a first-wave standpoint where we've taken about 125 of our generation 1 through 3 or 4 properties, some of which might be say 30 or 40 years old, they're in phenomenal locations. They drive very good occupancy and rent levels, but we're going to hopefully even see that much more opportunity once we've basically, taken them through the various stage of the elements that we would include in our generation brand-new properties. 
So that's working quite well. We're getting good reception from both customers and our employees as well. And then we're also now rolling that program into a number of markets nationally, which will include in the first quarter parts of Florida. We've touched many parts of the boroughs, if not all of those properties, we're going to go into other parts of New York. We've already gone into markets like Chicago, for instance, and the Carolina so anyway, we're pretty excited about what we're doing. Now from a cost standpoint, we've talked about this program in the context of ultimately being about $1.5 billion or more once we get through the entire portfolio. 2019, we will have spent about $110 million on a program and in 2020, we'll likely spend even a little bit more. Again, as we touched the market I talked to. So, so far we're very pleased. 
Now as we're doing this, we're also making some technological updates to the properties, where as we speak relighting interior LEDs on assets for both energy efficiency and again, better customer environments. We have begun changing out our assets control system, which is now based on a centralized system, which we never had before. It's just going to give us a lot of good data that we haven't had around customer activity. We're adding solar to a number of properties. So we've got a number of different elements of the overall program in motion like I mentioned very good feedback from it and like the results.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Great. And then, I just wanted to ask you to you last quarter you mentioned that the third-party management platform, which is largely geared to predevelopment and end development properties. Just given what looks like continued kind of deceleration in tr
componenttext: Great. And then, I just wanted to ask you to you last quarter you mentioned that the third-party management platform, which is largely geared to predevelopment and end development properties. Just given what looks like continued kind of deceleration in trends across the multiple markets, is there an opportunity to bring on or convert more independence, I guess, more aggressively to your platform or is that your strategy there to...

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Again, we're seeing our pipeline definitely continue to build. The pipeline is dominated by assets that are in various stages of development. That's pretty typical for, again, this kind of a platform, again, from what the industry as a whole has seen. We
componenttext: Again, we're seeing our pipeline definitely continue to build. The pipeline is dominated by assets that are in various stages of development. That's pretty typical for, again, this kind of a platform, again, from what the industry as a whole has seen. We have, however, also seen some opportunities to bring more stabilized assets into the program to. And again, number of owners are clearly interested and are anxious to come into our platform because they like and see the amount of revenue generation that we can provide to them based on all the metrics that we're able to, again, we went to their assets whether given truly based on our brand optimization, the optimization that we get through search our marketing efforts, the scale that we've got in markets. So again, it's program we're pleased relative to the momentum that we've got in that we signed in the quarter 13 additional assets. So today we've got about 75 properties in the program and as I've mentioned the backlog continues to build.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Thomas of KeyBanc Capital Markets.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to follow-up on that and on rates. Tom, you mentioned move-in rents were down 5% of the quarter. They've been down since late 2017 and the decrease in move-in rents seem to be increasing a bit here. As you think about where we are in the cycle
componenttext: Just wanted to follow-up on that and on rates. Tom, you mentioned move-in rents were down 5% of the quarter. They've been down since late 2017 and the decrease in move-in rents seem to be increasing a bit here. As you think about where we are in the cycle with regards to supply and the absorption of new supply that's taking place across the industry, it sounds like you're still seeing some good traction the occupancy side, but where do you think we are in the process of seeing asking rents adjust, any thoughts on that?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. I do think if you go back several years at a consistent trend of using move-in rate or to drive volume, it really is a market-by-market dynamic. So as we think about where it's going in future years, a lot of it will be dependent on what happens in t
componenttext: Yes. I do think if you go back several years at a consistent trend of using move-in rate or to drive volume, it really is a market-by-market dynamic. So as we think about where it's going in future years, a lot of it will be dependent on what happens in those markets. So just looking at move-in rates for the third quarter for example, you have markets like Los Angeles or Phoenix where [ Europe ] going low to mid-single digits on move-in rates given what's going on there. The flip side is you've got Florida markets like Miami and Tampa, which are being impacted by new supply and those move-in rates are down call it 5% to 10%, I through Houston into that bucket as well. And so the move-in rates were using non-across the board it's really a tactic to drive volume in areas where we're competing for new customers in a more competitive environment. As we move into 2020, we're likely to see the mix of those markets continue to shift. So as we've spoken about in the past, looking back at the markets that were more challenged in prior year, we've seen some of those markets actually improve meaningfully. So market like Chicago or Washington, D.C. there was many more impacted early on in the cycle. We've seen better traction this year than they were last year. So as we had a into 2020, it's going to be a different mix of markets. But I'll let Joe speak to new supply in aggregate by market, but it's a pretty dynamic management on our end as we seek to maximize revenue within those local submarkets.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And then I realized you send out far of your rent increase letters I suppose into the off-peak leasing season, but there's a current environment that you're experiencing here in the market, does it cause it to consider using up a little bit on the n
componenttext: Okay. And then I realized you send out far of your rent increase letters I suppose into the off-peak leasing season, but there's a current environment that you're experiencing here in the market, does it cause it to consider using up a little bit on the number of customers that you might be sending letters to or the rate at which you might push? And also, can you remind us whether there is sort of a governor in place around how much of a percent above street you'll increase existing customers rates?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. So strategy wise we plan on using consistent plans through the fourth and next year's first quarter in the slow season. So we do send rental rate increases throughout the year and we'll do so in the coming quarters. In terms of the magnitude in the
componenttext:
Sure. So strategy wise we plan on using consistent plans through the fourth and next year's first quarter in the slow season. So we do send rental rate increases throughout the year and we'll do so in the coming quarters. In terms of the magnitude in the quantity, we're looking to optimize that at the tenant level. We think we do better on that year-end and year out. So ultimately what we're seeking to do is maximize revenue. So we take into consideration the probabilities of vacates as well as the cost of that vacates replacing that tenant et cetera. So I think it varies throughout the year, but consistent strategies and no change or more conservatism or more aggressiveness as we get into the next few quarters. 
In terms of a governor, there are things in place that we use in order to make sure that we are maximizing the revenue overtime. And so there's different governors in place and different strategies we use and different types of environment, but certainly, street rate and the rate in which a new customer would move-in is a key component of the strategy. So it's time to get high or about street rates the cost of that tenant leaving is higher.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa of Evercore ISI.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Steve Sakwa of Evercore ISI.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: First question, I guess, is just in terms of the sort of the monthly trends you saw on the third quarter, was there anything noticeable as it relates to kind of the same-store revenue trend that relies occupancy ended kind of on the strong note at the end
componenttext: First question, I guess, is just in terms of the sort of the monthly trends you saw on the third quarter, was there anything noticeable as it relates to kind of the same-store revenue trend that relies occupancy ended kind of on the strong note at the end of the period and average occupancy was up 40? And I'm just curious kind of how things trended throughout the quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. So in terms of the operating trends for the quarterly, we actually did see improving trends from July through September. We did do some things in September that aided that, including our typical Labor Day sale that we extended a bit this year to dri
componenttext: Sure. So in terms of the operating trends for the quarterly, we actually did see improving trends from July through September. We did do some things in September that aided that, including our typical Labor Day sale that we extended a bit this year to drive traffic, and ultimately we like that from a revenue standpoint, both in the quarter as well as moving forward. So we did see modestly improving trends through the quarter from July through September. And as we head into October generally consistent trends. So nothing really to speak to.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I realize you guys don't provide guidance but historically, kind of the guidepost for revenue growth has been to look at that annual contract rent per foot and sort of look at the average occupancy and the end of period occupancy. And for the th
componenttext: Okay. And I realize you guys don't provide guidance but historically, kind of the guidepost for revenue growth has been to look at that annual contract rent per foot and sort of look at the average occupancy and the end of period occupancy. And for the third quarter, that kind of gave you a range of [ 1 3 to 1 6 ] and that the actual number came in a little bit below that. As you look at the fourth quarter it's kind of penciling in for call it 50 basis points to about 80 basis points, which would be sort of further slowdown. Is there something we're sort of should be thinking about as we head into Q4 and into next year?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: No. Steve, what I would point you to that those are metrics that we think create guidelines. I mean, there can obviously be some variation in and out of different conditions. But at the end of the day they're relatively within the zone. And what I would p
componenttext: No. Steve, what I would point you to that those are metrics that we think create guidelines. I mean, there can obviously be some variation in and out of different conditions. But at the end of the day they're relatively within the zone. And what I would point to as well, Tom mentioned that through October, we've seen consistent occupancy impact. And again, that's intentional, meaning, we saw that in the quarter 70% or 70 basis point increase. And at the moment, it's in about that same zone. So it ties to the strategic things that we're continuing to do. And again, at tough acquisition, customer acquisition environment to do something that others may be don't have the same capabilities to do, which is really still in this environment lift occupancy with a broader intent of that ultimately gives us many things we like around revenue generation. So we're continuing to do that, and I think we've set the stage for Q4 pretty well as we intended to do.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. And I guess, just lastly on the marketing expense. Is there any way to sort of just help separate kind of the actual cost-per-click or the actual cost from kind of the Google search versus the kind of the increased usage of the Google search and so
componenttext: Okay. And I guess, just lastly on the marketing expense. Is there any way to sort of just help separate kind of the actual cost-per-click or the actual cost from kind of the Google search versus the kind of the increased usage of the Google search and so to search paid advertising types stuff. So I'm just trying to sort of disaggregate the pricing increases versus, I guess, volume of usage?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. I would -- without getting into specifics around keyword, but strategies or otherwise I would say it's a good mix of both increased cost-per-click as well as the increased bits to drive volume. So a good mix of both.
componenttext: Sure. I would -- without getting into specifics around keyword, but strategies or otherwise I would say it's a good mix of both increased cost-per-click as well as the increased bits to drive volume. So a good mix of both.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Ki Bin Kim of SunTrust.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just want to follow-up on Steve's questions. First on the expense. This elevated level is obviously purposeful, it shouldn't be a surprised. I'm curious though, as we head into next year, has we comped higher numbers? Is this new norm? And we should expec
componenttext: Just want to follow-up on Steve's questions. First on the expense. This elevated level is obviously purposeful, it shouldn't be a surprised. I'm curious though, as we head into next year, has we comped higher numbers? Is this new norm? And we should expect increases from here this level on up or is this level just kind of artificially high because it's part of our unique -- part of a strategy for today that might normalize lower going forward?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: So Kim, I think there's a couple of things I'd highlight. One is, clearly we pulled on this lever pretty hard in the third quarter and just to get some of the strategy thing behind it from a revenue standpoint. But I think stepping back, it's managed very
componenttext:
So Kim, I think there's a couple of things I'd highlight. One is, clearly we pulled on this lever pretty hard in the third quarter and just to get some of the strategy thing behind it from a revenue standpoint. But I think stepping back, it's managed very much dynamically at the local keyword level. And so as we monitor what the returns are, we're going to our strategies there thereafter. So we can't predict exactly what's going to happen going forward. I would kind of step back in terms of advertising spend and think about where we are and what we're backing from a customer acquisition standpoint just provide a little historical context. So if you go back in time advertising as a percentage of revenue for Public Storage at the end of the last cycle beginning of the cycle, however, between call it 2% and 3% of revenue. As the customer acquisition environment got very healthy end certainly fundamentals were very solid in the beginning in the middle part of the cycle, we decreased our advertising spend. In 2016 for example, advertising spend was just a touch over 1% of revenue in the same store pool. 
We're looking now year-to-date, it's hovering just under 2%. So it gives you some context that we have always been increasing in marketing spend, we've been doing so from a low base in what was a very attractive customer acquisition environment in 2014, '15, '16 and now we're at a certainly more challenging and competitive environment. We're using that tool like we have in the past to drive new move-ins and occupancy.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. That's helpful. And going back to the revenue questions on street rates, so this quarter your move-in rates were down 5.3%. You extended the Labor Day sale a little bit longer. You got the occupancy gains that you're looking for with lower rates and
componenttext: Okay. That's helpful. And going back to the revenue questions on street rates, so this quarter your move-in rates were down 5.3%. You extended the Labor Day sale a little bit longer. You got the occupancy gains that you're looking for with lower rates and higher advertising. So I'm just curious if you're setting your yourself up or same-store revenue growth through potentially reaccelerate in the fourth quarter because maybe your -- the customers you've drawn into the company are paying that 50% off rate, some will move-out, some will stay and they'll get the higher rent. Maybe the occupancy is encashing day 1. So maybe there's some built-in gains to recapture in the fourth quarter. I know that's a big question, but it just maybe feels like 4Q might look better than 3Q.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: So Kim, what I say is, we obviously like the strategies we see in the third quarter. Some of them have short-term impacts certainly. We're looking them to manage medium to longer term revenue and ultimate customer lifetime value through that lifetime. In
componenttext: So Kim, what I say is, we obviously like the strategies we see in the third quarter. Some of them have short-term impacts certainly. We're looking them to manage medium to longer term revenue and ultimate customer lifetime value through that lifetime. In terms of whether where we're accelerating or decelerating, we continue to face real challenges from an operating standpoint, particularly on move-ins in many of our supply impacted markets, that's not going to change as we get into the fourth quarter and we continue to sue that through October. You're looking at certain markets that have been more challenging and you look at markets like Atlanta for example, that has had a more challenging third quarter and into the fourth quarter, and we're going to continue to see markets like that, that will be a drag on both move-in volumes as well as revenues we get in the fourth quarter.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Ronald Kamdem of Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our next question comes from the line of Ronald Kamdem of Morgan Stanley.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Two quick ones. First is just you sort of did a good job laying out some of the markets that you mentioned or may be seeing elevated supply. Just do you have a sense of when I think about private equity and private capital investors, has the appetite for
componenttext: Two quick ones. First is just you sort of did a good job laying out some of the markets that you mentioned or may be seeing elevated supply. Just do you have a sense of when I think about private equity and private capital investors, has the appetite for the product from their standpoint changed at all or is it still pretty attractive sort of asset class, even in those markets that may be -- may have had maybe too much supplier early on in the cycle?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, Ronald, I think, again, that investor type continues to look at self-storage as a product in very positive terms. We're seeing more entrants either come into or basically kind of scout the industry variety of different ways where we're seeing, again,
componenttext: Yes, Ronald, I think, again, that investor type continues to look at self-storage as a product in very positive terms. We're seeing more entrants either come into or basically kind of scout the industry variety of different ways where we're seeing, again, that type of investment vehicles come in through a variety of different markets. More often they're not you're looking for scale, which can be challenging from time-to-time. Cap rates really haven't adjusted for the most part, but there's definitely a fair amount of capital that still wants to come into the market. And some of those buyers maybe thinking in terms that I would say could be somewhat risky because they may be basing it off of pro formas but may or may not make sense. May be based on levels of traction that we're seeing 1 or 2 years ago, that have certainly continue to change. So it's a new and different dynamic that's coming to the sector and by all accounts, we don't see that shifting anytime soon.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: All right. My second question, I think on the previous calls, you sort of mentioned that sort of the acquisition opportunity may be had increased I think you mentioned buying some assets off of auction. Just maybe you giving up did on that. Is that someth
componenttext: All right. My second question, I think on the previous calls, you sort of mentioned that sort of the acquisition opportunity may be had increased I think you mentioned buying some assets off of auction. Just maybe you giving up did on that. Is that something you seeing? And what does that mean for potential acquisition volumes next year, is there something we could see ramp significantly?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. So again, statistically obviously you can see, again, through what we've done in the third quarter and then what we've got in a pipeline whether we've already closed on contract for the fourth quarter. We're likely to acquire plus or minus about $37
componenttext:
Sure. So again, statistically obviously you can see, again, through what we've done in the third quarter and then what we've got in a pipeline whether we've already closed on contract for the fourth quarter. We're likely to acquire plus or minus about $375 million of assets this year, and that's 2 assets of what we did from our acquisition volume in 2018, for instance. And as I talked to last couple of quarters, we do see more and more owners coming to us in a variety of different stages, whether they've already built assets, they may be in the first year or 2 lease up, they're not making either pro formas or revenue projections and they've got some level of, I would call it, anxiety. I wouldn't call it pronounced flat-out stress at this point, but there's definitely more anxiety related conversations that we're having. By virtue of that, we're seeing sellers being far more reasonable around valuations. That's clearly what has led to some of the acquisition volume that we've already done this year and continue to see come our way. We've been able to capture some really nice assets on a number of markets that we wanted to build scale into. And we're anticipating that there is more of that to come. 
And the other factor that I would tell you that is starting to percolator bit more that what we've seen recently is what I would call it entitled land where there an owner, again, may have acquire his property 1, 2 or 3 years ago, again, anticipating pro formas that they felt confident about 1, 2, 3 years ago, clearly things have shifted. They're reassessing their own development returns and we're seeing more opportunities to actually engage and particularly and potentially find some interesting opportunities there.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Eric Frankel of Green Street Advisors.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Eric Frankel of Green Street Advisors.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I don't want to see the marketing expense issue to that, but I would like to maybe to just understand that rise and the cost-per-click phenomenon. Is that just related to just larger more overall supply and some more competitiveness on the market that's c
componenttext: I don't want to see the marketing expense issue to that, but I would like to maybe to just understand that rise and the cost-per-click phenomenon. Is that just related to just larger more overall supply and some more competitiveness on the market that's causing people to be more aggressive marketing space? Is it storage? Is it something else? What do you think is the issue or is it something -- or is a just a monopoly practice of search?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: No. I think it's a good mix of a lot of factors you highlighted. It's a combination of your traditional operators being willing to spend more, to acquire more customers. As we've increased our spend, we've seen incremental volume and I suspect others have
componenttext:
No. I think it's a good mix of a lot of factors you highlighted. It's a combination of your traditional operators being willing to spend more, to acquire more customers. As we've increased our spend, we've seen incremental volume and I suspect others have as well. And so there's a component of your existing folks being more competitive. Certainly, the Google platform is a great 1 in the fact that its action based. So they let us compete within their stand box. And so, the environment is more competitive and you see folks being more aggressive in the cost-per-click. There also not only your big public REITs, but also your regional operators that have been more aggressive as well as some of your nontraditional storage folks like ballet, for instance, with some of those operators have been more aggressive in cost-per-click as well. 
So that all adds to a higher cost-per-click environment, which as we look at our spend, that's a component of it. But then we need to, again, at the local level do we like the bids the volumes that we seeing what we get if we increase, what we get if we decrease and that's what we're managing. And ultimately, as I spoke earlier, we like the returns. We'll see whether the rest of the environment and the rest of our competitors like the returns as cost-per-click continue to go higher, but we like what we're seeing.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Okay. Just another quick follow-up regarding, I guess, search. It's obviously quite a new initiative but the UPS announced their an initial sort of storage business. Do you have any thoughts on the self-storage industry going forward, if that model to exp
componenttext: Okay. Just another quick follow-up regarding, I guess, search. It's obviously quite a new initiative but the UPS announced their an initial sort of storage business. Do you have any thoughts on the self-storage industry going forward, if that model to expand that model?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes Eric, definitely, interesting announcement. And we've tracked, we've experimented, we've done a variety of different customer surveys around this whole concept of ballet on-demand type platform. And thus far, we continue to receive very little disrupt
componenttext: Yes Eric, definitely, interesting announcement. And we've tracked, we've experimented, we've done a variety of different customer surveys around this whole concept of ballet on-demand type platform. And thus far, we continue to receive very little disruption and/or change in our own customer behavior because we continue to see pretty distinct differences between what that product offering is compared to what traditional self-storage is. So the one thing that UPS obviously has that others prior have not is more of a logistical network. The platform right now is based on kind of a bin concept. So not clearly understanding what way it might evolve overtime. They're testing it out in 1 market. So we're going to continue to watch and understand as we have with other platforms. But overall the whole ballet model we continue to see as 1 that might be more akin to a traditional moving and storage type customer versus a traditional self-storage customer. A big difference to a self-storage model is you literally pay for access each and every time you want to goods, and then at the end of the day you don't even know where they are. So those are 2 pretty big hurdles relative to what, again, a core self-storage customer traditionally wants, which is access and basically, again, knowing that they can, again, get to their goods without having to pay fees to do so. So we'll continue to track it and see what it evolves.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Todd Stender of Wells Fargo.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just back to the elevated marketing spend. definitely tipped to end of negative same-store NOI territory, it's hitting the stock today as you know. But I just wanted to get a sense of what you guys are thinking about guidance maybe just for some key metri
componenttext: Just back to the elevated marketing spend. definitely tipped to end of negative same-store NOI territory, it's hitting the stock today as you know. But I just wanted to get a sense of what you guys are thinking about guidance maybe just for some key metrics to set the right expectations obviously. You're not running your business on a quarterly basis, it's for the long-term, but when you get an outsized expense item like this that pops up that does contribute to you guys trending negative, just wanted to get a sense of maybe setting the right expectations going forward.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. So, you're right, we don't provide guidance and we don't manage for the short-term and we talk about how we thought about the advertising spend for the quarter. In terms of line-by-line expectations for expense growth, I would point you to our 10-Q
componenttext: Sure. So, you're right, we don't provide guidance and we don't manage for the short-term and we talk about how we thought about the advertising spend for the quarter. In terms of line-by-line expectations for expense growth, I would point you to our 10-Q particularly in the MD&A where we do walk through what the trends are within each of those items. I won't go through it in detail because obviously, the folks on the phone can go through and read it. But I think the expense pressure is generally continued to be it property taxes, property level payroll and the like. So even away from marketing expenses, there's no question that operating expenses have been more under pressure this year, we think that's likely to continue for many of those line items. But I pointed to 10-Q in terms of some guidance as to where we're headed.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller of JP Morgan.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Michael Mueller of JP Morgan.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Just going back to the other topic of rent growth, realized rent growth. I mean, what, I guess, was different in Q3 compared to Q2? Because if we look at the prior quarter going from Q1 to Q2, we saw a pickup in the growth rate, we saw pick up in REVPAF a
componenttext: Just going back to the other topic of rent growth, realized rent growth. I mean, what, I guess, was different in Q3 compared to Q2? Because if we look at the prior quarter going from Q1 to Q2, we saw a pickup in the growth rate, we saw pick up in REVPAF as well but then it ended up even with the marketing spend coming in maybe a little bit better than half of what the Q2 was. So I guess, was there anything at normal and that you see is that Q2 or was there something abnormal and what appears to be the imprint the Q3 levels of 0.7% realized rent growth and 1.1% REVPAF growth?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. I wouldn't point to anything, in particular. As you move through the second quarter and into the third quarter, the busy season with lower move-in rates that is a big drag through those quarters on contract rent growth. And you've seen that this yea
componenttext: Sure. I wouldn't point to anything, in particular. As you move through the second quarter and into the third quarter, the busy season with lower move-in rates that is a big drag through those quarters on contract rent growth. And you've seen that this year, you've seen in previous years as well. So there's nothing really new there. Maybe pointing to 1 factor that may be made in the second quarter little bit better in the third quarter maybe a little bit worse, if you look at discount trends for example, which are component of revenue, discounts are down almost 7% in the second quarter were down about 4% in the third quarter. So there's lots of moving pieces there, but generally if you look back, while we've been battling this new supply between second quarter and third quarter, we've seen contract rent growth decelerate over that time period pretty simply because we've been using lower rates in many of our markets only to drive that volume as those folks moving during the summer that contract rent growth declines.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of Citi.
componenttext: Our next question comes from the line of Smedes Rose of Citi.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: It's Michael Bill on for Smedes. Last couple of years you've tapped on your debt market. So you're sitting at about $1.5 billion of U.S. unsecured and you've put some capital on Europe from the natural hedge for your staking in Shurgard as well as sort of
componenttext: It's Michael Bill on for Smedes. Last couple of years you've tapped on your debt market. So you're sitting at about $1.5 billion of U.S. unsecured and you've put some capital on Europe from the natural hedge for your staking in Shurgard as well as sort of curious what your appetite today is taking additional debt? I know you redeemed preferred and reissued, but I don't know if there was an appetite getting how low rates are to raise that capital?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. Thanks, Michael. I think as we've talked about in the past appetite to add incremental debt as well as incremental preferred as we have uses of capital. So, so far this year, we have issued over $1 billion of capital. As you've highlighted our prefe
componenttext: Sure. Thanks, Michael. I think as we've talked about in the past appetite to add incremental debt as well as incremental preferred as we have uses of capital. So, so far this year, we have issued over $1 billion of capital. As you've highlighted our preferred activity is largely been to refinance, existing preferreds and we're hopeful we have the opportunity to continue to do that as we move through the fourth quarter, there's a series that becomes callable in the fourth quarter. But stepping back from a strategy standpoint, we plan on using both unsecured debt, which we can get attractive rates to your point, as well as provide stock, which are higher cost, but historically speaking right now is offering very historically attractive coupons, sub 5% is what we achieved in September. So we like both markets and we plan on using both going forward.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: I guess, is there an appetite to maybe take advantage of the spreads you can get to increase cash flow when your operating fundamentals are a little bit weaker, right, so take advantage of being able to lock in 10, 20 or even 30 year paper refinancing pre
componenttext: I guess, is there an appetite to maybe take advantage of the spreads you can get to increase cash flow when your operating fundamentals are a little bit weaker, right, so take advantage of being able to lock in 10, 20 or even 30 year paper refinancing preferreds that captured 250 basis points of positive spread and at least help offset some of dilution from a weaker core portfolio?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Sure. So we have been reducing the cost of our preferred portfolio by refinancing it. We like the $4 billion preferred we have outstanding. We think it's a very good source of permanent capital. Taking what you could said to the extreme revolver and reduc
componenttext: Sure. So we have been reducing the cost of our preferred portfolio by refinancing it. We like the $4 billion preferred we have outstanding. We think it's a very good source of permanent capital. Taking what you could said to the extreme revolver and reduce a first, but from a standpoint, we like that permanent capital stack but we'll seek to refinance into better rates. And going forward in order to fund acquisition and development activity, we will be using both debt as we did earlier in the year as well as preferred.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: And then just going back to the valley discussion. It's a mix basis combination with iron Mountain from a strategic perspective gave them the distribution and logistics support that others didn't have before. Have you seen any impact at all as they've gon
componenttext: And then just going back to the valley discussion. It's a mix basis combination with iron Mountain from a strategic perspective gave them the distribution and logistics support that others didn't have before. Have you seen any impact at all as they've gone deeper into a lot of the markets you're in?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, Michael, I wouldn't say we've seen anything pronounced in different. It still goes back to the way I characterize the product as a whole. So again, we've seen very little disruption and again, change, again, the core customer that continues to look f
componenttext: Yes, Michael, I wouldn't say we've seen anything pronounced in different. It still goes back to the way I characterize the product as a whole. So again, we've seen very little disruption and again, change, again, the core customer that continues to look for all the benefits of a self-storage product. So we're going to continue to monitor and see what comes from any of these realignments that are going on. It's interesting that went in a different direction and actually brought hard assets, which are different from a traditional model. So, again, this into a lot of movement in that space as a whole and we'll continue to see what evolves from it.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: And then my last one. And then, I just recognize there is a lot of fires going on within California right now. And I do hope all of your friends, family and coworkers are safe. Disaster unfortunately is one of the drivers at your demand. Is there any sort
componenttext: And then my last one. And then, I just recognize there is a lot of fires going on within California right now. And I do hope all of your friends, family and coworkers are safe. Disaster unfortunately is one of the drivers at your demand. Is there any sort of thought in terms of what this could be doing perhaps lack of demand because may be facilities are closed and there is no power, and then as a drive any of given California as your large market?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes. Again, we're obviously keeping a close eye on this and appreciate the good wishes because, yes there's a lot of stress in some of the areas both northern and southern California with the fire season that we have at the end. But at the moment, we have
componenttext: Yes. Again, we're obviously keeping a close eye on this and appreciate the good wishes because, yes there's a lot of stress in some of the areas both northern and southern California with the fire season that we have at the end. But at the moment, we haven't seen any direct impact to our own portfolio. And what can be unusual what fire events is traditionally they and themselves really don't create a lot of elevated activity. So obviously that's always dependent upon where the specific files are and to what degree -- what comes with. They seem to be like-for-like very different events and say hurricane where we see a lot more broader disruption or impact to a particular market, but we're keeping our fingers crossed that California can get through this in a good way, but there's a lot of stress out there.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Our last question will come from the line of Jon Peterson of Jefferies.
componenttext: Our last question will come from the line of Jon Peterson of Jefferies.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Great. I've got a few public players out there that do that land to some of the other self-storage owners. I'm wondering is that something you guys have considered doing possibly as a way to grow your third-party management business to leverage cost of ca
componenttext: Great. I've got a few public players out there that do that land to some of the other self-storage owners. I'm wondering is that something you guys have considered doing possibly as a way to grow your third-party management business to leverage cost of capital and just given your position in the industry?

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: Yes, Jon, I wouldn't tell you that an intentional focus point of ours right now. There is a lot of capital that's in the space at large. So we are going to continue to be more focused on growing our own portfolio through our own direct investments et cete
componenttext: Yes, Jon, I wouldn't tell you that an intentional focus point of ours right now. There is a lot of capital that's in the space at large. So we are going to continue to be more focused on growing our own portfolio through our own direct investments et cetera, and really haven't tapped into kind of a lending arm. And it seem far more different things that we can continue with our balance sheet.

headline: Public Storage, Q3 2019 Earnings Call, Oct 30, 2019
componenttextpreview: And that was our final question. I'd like to turn the floor back to management for any additional or closing remarks.
componenttext: And that was our final question. I'd like to turn the floor back to management for any additional or closing remarks.
